member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext.System#IDisposable#Dispose
member.summary: This will dispose and reset all resources used to run the application
member.remarks: IMPORTANT: Never dispose this object if you require the Umbraco application to run, disposing this object is generally used for unit testing and when your application is shutting down after you have booted Umbraco.

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext.Current
member.summary: Singleton accessor

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext.ApplicationCache
member.summary: Returns the application wide cache accessor
member.remarks: Any caching that is done in the application (app wide) should be done through this property

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext.OriginalRequestUrl
member.summary: The original/first url that the web application executes
member.remarks: we need to set the initial url in our ApplicationContext, this is so our keep alive service works and this must exist on a global context because the keep alive service doesn't run in a web context. we are NOT going to put a lock on this because locking will slow down the application and we don't really care if two threads write to this at the exact same time during first page hit. see: http://issues.umbraco.org/issue/U4-2059

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext.DatabaseContext
member.summary: Gets the current DatabaseContext
member.remarks: Internal set is generally only used for unit tests

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext.Services
member.summary: Gets the current ServiceContext
member.remarks: Internal set is generally only used for unit tests

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationEventHandler
member.summary: A plugin type that allows developers to execute code during the Umbraco bootup process
member.remarks:
Allows you to override the methods that you would like to execute code for: ApplicationInitialized, ApplicationStarting, ApplicationStarted.
By default none of these methods will execute if the Umbraco application is not configured or if the Umbraco database is not configured, however if you need these methods to execute even if either of these are not configured you can override the properties: ExecuteWhenApplicationNotConfigured and ExecuteWhenDatabaseNotConfigured

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.IApplicationEventHandler
member.summary: Custom IApplicationStartupHandler that auto subscribes to the applications events

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.IApplicationEventHandler.OnApplicationInitialized(Umbraco.Core.UmbracoApplicationBase,Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext)
member.summary: ApplicationContext is created and other static objects that require initialization have been setup

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.IApplicationEventHandler.OnApplicationStarting(Umbraco.Core.UmbracoApplicationBase,Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext)
member.summary: All resolvers have been initialized but resolution is not frozen so they can be modified in this method

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.IApplicationEventHandler.OnApplicationStarted(Umbraco.Core.UmbracoApplicationBase,Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext)
member.summary: Bootup is completed, this allows you to perform any other bootup logic required for the application. Resolution is frozen so now they can be used to resolve instances.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationEventHandler.ApplicationInitialized(Umbraco.Core.UmbracoApplicationBase,Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext)
member.summary: Overridable method to execute when the ApplicationContext is created and other static objects that require initialization have been setup

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationEventHandler.ApplicationStarting(Umbraco.Core.UmbracoApplicationBase,Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext)
member.summary: OVerridable method to execute when All resolvers have been initialized but resolution is not frozen so they can be modified in this method

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationEventHandler.ApplicationStarted(Umbraco.Core.UmbracoApplicationBase,Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext)
member.summary: Overridable method to execute when Bootup is completed, this allows you to perform any other bootup logic required for the application. Resolution is frozen so now they can be used to resolve instances.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationEventHandler.ShouldExecute(Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext)
member.summary: Determine if the methods should execute based on the configuration status of the application.

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationEventHandler.ExecuteWhenApplicationNotConfigured
member.summary: A flag to determine if the overridable methods for this class will execute even if the Umbraco application is not configured
member.remarks: An Umbraco Application is not configured when it requires a new install or upgrade. When the latest version in the assembly does not match the version in the config.

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.ApplicationEventHandler.ExecuteWhenDatabaseNotConfigured
member.summary: A flag to determine if the overridable methods for this class will execute even if the Umbraco database is not configured
member.remarks: The Umbraco database is not configured when we cannot connect to the database or when the database tables are not installed.

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.CodeAnnotations.UmbracoProposedPublicAttribute
member.summary: Marks the program elements that Umbraco is considering making public.

remarks.para: Indicates that Umbraco considers making the (currently internal) program element public at some point in the future, but the decision is not fully made yet and is still pending reviews.
Note that it is not a commitment to make the program element public. It may not ever become public.
The issue tracker should contain more details, discussion, and planning.

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.Configuration.UmbracoConfigurationSection
member.summary: Represents an Umbraco section within the configuration file.

remarks.para: The requirement for these sections is to be read-only.
However for unit tests purposes it is internally possible to override some values, and then calling >ResetSection should cancel these changes and bring the section back to what it was originally.
The UmbracoSettings.For{T} method will return a section, either one that is in the configuration file, or a section that was created with default values.

member.summary: Internal singleton to handle the numbering of subfolders within the Media-folder. When this class is initiated it will look for numbered subfolders and select the highest number, which will be the start point for the naming of the next subfolders. If no subfolders exists then the starting point will be 1000, ie. /media/1000/koala.jpg

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Models.EntityBase.TracksChangesEntityBase.ResetDirtyProperties(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Resets dirty properties by clearing the dictionary used to track changes.

member.remarks: Please note that resetting the dirty properties could potentially obstruct the saving of a new or updated entity.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Models.EntityBase.TracksChangesEntityBase.SetPropertyValueAndDetectChanges``1(System.Func{``0,``0},``0,System.Reflection.PropertyInfo)
member.summary: Used by inheritors to set the value of properties, this will detect if the property value actually changed and if it did it will ensure that the property has a dirty flag set.
member.returns: returns true if the value changed
member.remarks: This is required because we don't want a property to show up as "dirty" if the value is the same. For example, when we save a document type, nearly all properties are flagged as dirty just because we've 'reset' them, but they are all set to the same value, so it's really not dirty.

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.IO.FileSystemWrapper
member.summary: All custom file systems that are based upon another IFileSystem should inherit from FileSystemWrapper
member.remarks:
An IFileSystem is generally used as a base file system, for example like a PhysicalFileSystem or an S3FileSystem. Then, other custom file systems are wrapped upon these files systems like MediaFileSystem, etc... All of the custom file systems must inherit from FileSystemWrapper.
This abstract class just wraps the 'real' IFileSystem object passed in to its constructor.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.MacroErrorBehaviour.Inline
member.summary: Default umbraco behavior - show an inline error within the macro but allow the page to continue rendering.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.MacroErrorBehaviour.Silent
member.summary: Silently eat the error and do not display the offending macro.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.MacroErrorBehaviour.Throw
member.summary: Throw an exception which can be caught by the global error handler defined in Application_OnError. If no such error handler is defined then you'll see the Yellow Screen Of Death (YSOD) error page.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.RetryPolicy.NoRetry

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.RetryPolicy.DefaultFixed
member.summary: Returns a default policy that implements a fixed retry interval configured with the default retry strategy. The default retry policy treats all caught exceptions as transient errors.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.RetryPolicy.DefaultProgressive
member.summary: Returns a default policy that implements a progressive retry interval configured with the default retry strategy. The default retry policy treats all caught exceptions as transient errors.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.RetryPolicy.DefaultExponential
member.summary: Returns a default policy that implements a random exponential retry interval configured with the default retry strategy. The default retry policy treats all caught exceptions as transient errors.

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingMode
member.summary: Defines the possible throttling modes in SQL Azure.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingMode.NoThrottling
member.summary: Corresponds to "No Throttling" throttling mode whereby all SQL statements can be processed.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingMode.RejectUpdateInsert
member.summary: Corresponds to "Reject Update / Insert" throttling mode whereby SQL statements such as INSERT, UPDATE, CREATE TABLE and CREATE INDEX are rejected.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingMode.RejectAllWrites
member.summary: Corresponds to "Reject All Writes" throttling mode whereby SQL statements such as INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, CREATE, DROP are rejected.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingMode.RejectAll
member.summary: Corresponds to "Reject All" throttling mode whereby all SQL statements are rejected.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingMode.Unknown
member.summary: Corresponds to an unknown throttling mode whereby throttling mode cannot be determined with certainty.

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingType
member.summary: Defines the possible throttling types in SQL Azure.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingType.None
member.summary: Indicates that no throttling was applied to a given resource.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingType.Soft
member.summary: Corresponds to a Soft throttling type. Soft throttling is applied when machine resources such as, CPU, IO, storage, and worker threads exceed predefined safety thresholds despite the load balancer’s best efforts.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingType.Hard
member.summary: Corresponds to a Hard throttling type. Hard throttling is applied when the machine is out of resources, for example storage space. With hard throttling, no new connections are allowed to the databases hosted on the machine until resources are freed up.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottlingType.Unknown
member.summary: Corresponds to an unknown throttling type in the event when the throttling type cannot be determined with certainty.

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottledResourceType
member.summary: Defines the types of resources in SQL Azure which may be subject to throttling conditions.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottledResourceType.PhysicalDatabaseSpace
member.summary: Corresponds to "Physical Database Space" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottledResourceType.PhysicalLogSpace
member.summary: Corresponds to "Physical Log File Space" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottledResourceType.LogWriteIoDelay
member.summary: Corresponds to "Transaction Log Write IO Delay" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottledResourceType.DataReadIoDelay
member.summary: Corresponds to "Database Read IO Delay" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottledResourceType.Cpu
member.summary: Corresponds to "CPU" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottledResourceType.DatabaseSize
member.summary: Corresponds to "Database Size" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottledResourceType.WorkerThreads
member.summary: Corresponds to "SQL Worker Thread Pool" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottledResourceType.Internal
member.summary: Corresponds to an internal resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.Persistence.FaultHandling.ThrottledResourceType.Unknown
member.summary: Corresponds to an unknown resource type in the event when the actual resource cannot be determined with certainty.

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.LazyManyObjectsResolverBase`2
member.summary: The base class for all lazy many-objects resolvers.
member.typeparam: The type of the concrete resolver class.
The type of the resolved objects.

remarks.para: This is a special case resolver for when types get lazily resolved in order to resolve the actual types. This is useful for when there is some processing overhead (i.e. Type finding in assemblies) to return the Types used to instantiate the instances. In some these cases we don't want to have to type-find during application startup, only when we need to resolve the instances.
Important notes about this resolver: it does not support Insert or Remove and therefore does not support any ordering unless the types are marked with the WeightedPluginAttribute.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Models.IPublishedContent.GetProperty(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a property on the object based on an alias
member.remarks:
Although we do have a a property to return Properties of the object, in some cases a custom implementation may not know about all properties until specifically asked for one by alias.
This method is mostly used in places such as DynamicPublishedContent when trying to resolve a property based on an alias. In some cases Pulish Stores, a property value may exist in multiple places and we need to fallback to different cached locations therefore sometimes the 'Properties' collection may not be sufficient.

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.LegacyTransientObjectsResolver`2
member.summary: The base class for old legacy factories such as the DataTypeFactory or CacheResolverFactory.
member.typeparam: The type of the concrete resolver class.
The type of the resolved objects.
member.remarks: This class contains basic functionality to mimic the functionality in these old factories since they all return transient objects (though this should be changed) and the method GetById needs to lookup a type to an ID and since these old classes don't contain metadata, the objects need to be instantiated first to get their metadata, we then store this for use in the GetById method.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.LegacyTransientObjectsResolver`2.#ctor(System.Func{System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Type}})
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with an initial list of object types.
member.param: A function returning the list of object types.
member.remarks: We are creating Transient instances (new instances each time) because this is how the legacy code worked and I don't want to muck anything up by changing them to application based instances. TODO: However, it would make much more sense to do this and would speed up the application plus this would make the GetById method much easier.

member.summary: Returns the unique identifier of the type of a specified object.
member.returns: The unique identifier of the type of .

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.LegacyTransientObjectsResolver`2.GetById(System.Guid)
member.summary: Returns a new instance for the type identified by its unique type identifier.
member.returns: The value of the type uniquely identified by .

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.LegacyTransientObjectsResolver`2.EnsureIsInitialized
member.summary: Populates the identifiers-to-types dictionnary.

remarks.para: This allow us to instantiate a type by ID since these legacy types doesn't contain any metadata.
We instanciate all types once to get their unique identifier, then build the dictionary so that when GetById is called, we can instanciate a single object.

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.Configuration.GlobalSettings.UmbracoMvcArea
member.summary: This returns the string of the MVC Area route.
member.remarks:
THIS IS TEMPORARY AND SHOULD BE REMOVED WHEN WE MIGRATE/UPDATE THE CONFIG SETTINGS TO BE A REAL CONFIG SECTION AND SHOULD PROBABLY BE HANDLED IN A MORE ROBUST WAY.
This will return the MVC area that we will route all custom routes through like surface controllers, etc... We will use the 'Path' (default ~/umbraco) to create it but since it cannot contain '/' and people may specify a path of ~/asdf/asdf/admin we will convert the '/' to '-' and use that as the path. its a bit lame but will work.
We also make sure that the virtual directory (SystemDirectories.Root) is stripped off first, otherwise we'd end up with something like "MyVirtualDirectory-Umbraco" instead of just "Umbraco".

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Logging.LoggingTaskExtension.LogErrors(System.Threading.Tasks.Task,System.Action{System.String,System.Exception})
member.summary:
This task shouldn't be waited on (as it's not guaranteed to run), and you shouldn't wait on the parent task either (because it might throw an exception that doesn't get handled). If you want to be waiting on something, use LogErrorsWaitable instead.
None of these methods are suitable for tasks that return a value. If you're wanting a result, you should probably be handling errors yourself.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Logging.LoggingTaskExtension.LogErrorsWaitable(System.Threading.Tasks.Task,System.Action{System.String,System.Exception})
member.summary:
This task can be waited on (as it's guaranteed to run), and you should wait on this rather than the parent task. Because it's guaranteed to run, it may be slower than using LogErrors, and you should consider using that method if you don't want to wait.
None of these methods are suitable for tasks that return a value. If you're wanting a result, you should probably be handling errors yourself.

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.Resolution
member.summary: Represents the status of objects resolution.

remarks.para: Before resolution is frozen it is possible to access its configuration, but not to get values.
Once resolution is frozen, it is not possible to access its configuration anymore, but it is possible to get values.

member.summary: Freezes resolution.
member.exception: resolution is already frozen.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.Resolution.Reset
member.summary: Resets resolution, ie unfreezes it and clears Frozen event.
member.remarks: To be used in unit tests.

member.name: E:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.Resolution.Frozen
member.summary: Occurs when resolution is frozen.
member.remarks: Occurs only once, since resolution can be frozen only once.

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.Resolution.IsFrozen
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether resolution of objects is frozen.

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.Resolution.Configuration
member.summary: Returns a disposable object that represents safe access to unfrozen resolution configuration.
member.remarks: Should be used in a using(Resolution.Configuration) { ... } mode.

member.name: P:Umbraco.Core.ObjectResolution.Resolution.DirtyBackdoorToConfiguration
member.summary: Returns a disposable object that reprents dirty access to temporarily unfrozen resolution configuration.

remarks.para: Should not be used.
Should be used in a using(Resolution.DirtyBackdoorToConfiguration) { ... } mode.
Because we just lift the frozen state, and we don't actually re-freeze, the Frozen event does not trigger.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Publishing.PublishingStrategy.Publish(Umbraco.Core.Models.IContent,System.Int32)
member.summary: Publishes a single piece of Content
member.param: Id of the User issueing the publish operation
member.returns: True if the publish operation was successfull and not cancelled, otherwise false

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Publishing.PublishingStrategy.PublishWithChildrenInternal(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Umbraco.Core.Models.IContent},System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Publishes a list of content items
member.param: By default this is set to true which means that it will publish any content item in the list that is completely unpublished and not visible on the front-end. If set to false, this will only publish content that is live on the front-end but has new versions that have yet to be published.
member.remarks:
This method becomes complex once we start to be able to cancel events or stop publishing a content item in any way because if a content item is not published then it's children shouldn't be published either. This rule will apply for the following conditions: * If a document fails to be published, do not proceed to publish it's children if: ** The document does not have a publish version ** The document does have a published version but the includeUnpublishedDocuments = false
In order to do this, we will order the content by level and begin by publishing each item at that level, then proceed to the next level and so on. If we detect that the above rule applies when the document publishing is cancelled we'll add it to the list of parentsIdsCancelled so that it's children don't get published.
Its important to note that all 'root' documents included in the list *will* be published regardless of the rules mentioned above (unless it is invalid)!! By 'root' documents we are referring to documents in the list with the minimum value for their 'level'. In most cases the 'root' documents will only be one document since under normal circumstance we only publish one document and its children. The reason we have to do this is because if a user is publishing a document and it's children, it is implied that the user definitely wants to publish it even if it has never been published before.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Publishing.PublishingStrategy.CheckCancellingOfChildPublishing(Umbraco.Core.Models.IContent,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Based on the information provider we'll check if we should cancel the publishing of this document's children
member.remarks: See remarks on method: PublishWithChildrenInternal

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.Strings.Utf8ToAsciiConverter
member.summary: Provides methods to convert Utf8 text to Ascii.

remarks.para: Tries to match characters such as accented eg "é" to Ascii equivalent eg "e".
Converts all "whitespace" characters to a single whitespace.
Removes all non-Utf8 (unicode) characters, so in fact it can sort-of "convert" Unicode to Ascii.
Replaces symbols with '?'.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Strings.Utf8ToAsciiConverter.ToAsciiString(System.String)
member.summary: Converts an Utf8 string into an Ascii string.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Strings.Utf8ToAsciiConverter.ToAsciiCharArray(System.String)
member.summary: Converts an Utf8 string into an array of Ascii characters.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Strings.Utf8ToAsciiConverter.ToAscii(System.Char[],System.Char[])
member.summary: Converts an array of Utf8 characters into an array of Ascii characters.
member.returns: The number of characters in the output array.
member.remarks: The caller must ensure that the output array is big enough.
member.exception: The output array is not big enough.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Strings.Utf8ToAsciiConverter.ToAscii(System.Char[],System.Int32,System.Char[],System.Int32@)
member.summary: Converts the character at position in input array of Utf8 characters and writes the converted value to output array of Ascii characters at position , and increments that position accordingly.

remarks.para: Adapted from various sources on the 'net including Lucene.Net.Analysis.ASCIIFoldingFilter.
Input should contain Utf8 characters exclusively and NOT Unicode.
Removes controls, normalizes whitespaces, replaces symbols by '?'.

member.summary: Cleans a string to produce a string that can safely be used in an alias.

remarks.para: The string will be cleaned in the context of the IShortStringHelper default culture.
A safe alias is [a-z][a-zA-Z0-9_]* although legacy will also accept '-', and '_' at the beginning.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Strings.IShortStringHelper.CleanStringForSafeFileName(System.String)
member.summary: Cleans a string, in the context of the invariant culture, to produce a string that can safely be used as a filename, both internally (on disk) and externally (as a url).
member.remarks: Legacy says this was used to "overcome an issue when Umbraco is used in IE in an intranet environment" but that issue is not documented.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Strings.IShortStringHelper.CleanStringForSafeFileName(System.String,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Cleans a string, in the context of a specified culture, to produce a string that can safely be used as a filename, both internally (on disk) and externally (as a url).
member.remarks: Legacy says this was used to "overcome an issue when Umbraco is used in IE in an intranet environment" but that issue is not documented.

Can expose surprising or bogus behavior.
Uses invariant culture everywhere.

member.remarks: Will be called by ShortStringHelperResolver when resolution freezes.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Strings.LegacyShortStringHelper.LegacyConvertStringCase(System.String,Umbraco.Core.Strings.CleanStringType)
member.summary: Filters a string to convert case, and more.

remarks.para: This is the legacy method, so we can't really change it, although it has issues (see unit tests).
It does more than "converting the case", and also remove spaces, etc.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Strings.LegacyShortStringHelper.LegacyToUrlAlias(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.String},System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts string to a URL alias.
member.param: if set to true replace double dashes.
if set to true strip non ASCII.
if set to true URL encode.
member.remarks: This ensures that ONLY ascii chars are allowed and of those ascii chars, only digits and lowercase chars, all punctuation, etc... are stripped out, however this method allows you to pass in string's to replace with the specified replacement character before the string is converted to ascii and it has invalid characters stripped out. This allows you to replace strings like & , etc.. with your replacement character before the automatic reduction.

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.TypeFinder
member.summary: A utility class to find all classes of a certain type by reflection in the current bin folder of the web application.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.TypeFinder.GetAllAssemblies
member.summary: lazily load a reference to all assemblies and only local assemblies. This is a modified version of: http://www.dominicpettifer.co.uk/Blog/44/how-to-get-a-reference-to-all-assemblies-in-the--bin-folder
member.remarks: We do this because we cannot use AppDomain.Current.GetAssemblies() as this will return only assemblies that have been loaded in the CLR, not all assemblies. See these threads: http://issues.umbraco.org/issue/U5-198 http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3552223/asp-net-appdomain-currentdomain-getassemblies-assemblies-missing-after-app http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2477787/difference-between-appdomain-getassemblies-and-buildmanager-getreferencedassembl

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.TypeFinder.GetBinAssemblies
member.summary: Returns only assemblies found in the bin folder that have been loaded into the app domain.
member.remarks: This will be used if we implement App_Plugins from Umbraco v5 but currently it is not used.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.TypeFinder.GetAssembliesWithKnownExclusions(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Reflection.Assembly})
member.summary: Return a list of found local Assemblies excluding the known assemblies we don't want to scan and exluding the ones passed in and excluding the exclusion list filter, the results of this are cached for perforance reasons.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.TypeFinder.GetFilteredAssemblies(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Reflection.Assembly},System.String[])
member.summary: Return a list of found local Assemblies and exluding the ones passed in and excluding the exclusion list filter

member.name: F:Umbraco.Core.TypeFinder.KnownAssemblyExclusionFilter
member.summary: this is our assembly filter to filter out known types that def dont contain types we'd like to find or plugins
member.remarks: NOTE the comma vs period... comma delimits the name in an Assembly FullName property so if it ends with comma then its an exact name match

member.name: T:Umbraco.Core.PluginManager
member.summary: Used to resolve all plugin types and cache them and is also used to instantiate plugin types
member.remarks:
This class should be used to resolve all plugin types, the TypeFinder should not be used directly!
This class can expose extension methods to resolve custom plugins
Before this class resolves any plugins it checks if the hash has changed for the DLLs in the /bin folder, if it hasn't it will use the cached resolved plugins that it has already found which means that no assembly scanning is necessary. This leads to much faster startup times.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.PluginManager.#ctor(Umbraco.Core.ApplicationContext,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new PluginManager with an ApplicationContext instance which ensures that the plugin xml file is cached temporarily until app startup completes.

member.summary: Creates a new PluginManager
member.param: If true will detect changes in the /bin folder and therefor load plugins from the cached plugins file if one is found. If false will never use the cache file for plugins

member.summary: Writes the assembly hash file

member.summary: Returns a unique hash for the combination of FileInfo objects passed in

member.summary: Converts the hash value of current plugins to long from string

member.summary: Attempts to resolve the list of plugin + assemblies found in the runtime for the base type 'T' passed in. If the cache file doesn't exist, fails to load, is corrupt or the type 'T' element is not found then a false attempt is returned.

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.PluginManager.DetectLegacyPluginListFile
member.summary: This will return true if the plugin list file is a legacy one
member.remarks: This method exists purely due to an error in 4.11. We were writing the plugin list file without the type resolution kind which will have caused some problems. Now we detect this legacy file and if it is detected we remove it so it can be recreated properly.

member.summary: Converts string to a URL alias.
member.param: if set to true replace double dashes.
if set to true strip non ASCII.
if set to true URL encode.
member.remarks: This ensures that ONLY ascii chars are allowed and of those ascii chars, only digits and lowercase chars, all punctuation, etc... are stripped out, however this method allows you to pass in string's to replace with the specified replacement character before the string is converted to ascii and it has invalid characters stripped out. This allows you to replace strings like & , etc.. with your replacement character before the automatic reduction.

Other helpers may use different parameters.

member.summary: Provides the evaluation context for fast execution and custom variables resolution.
member.remarks:
This class is responsible for resolving variables during dynamic expression execution.
Discussed in http://weblogs.asp.net/cazzu/archive/2003/10/07/30888.aspx
Author: Daniel Cazzulino, blog

member.name: M:Umbraco.Core.Xml.DynamicContext.AddVariable(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Adds the variable to the dynamic evaluation context.
member.param: The name of the variable to add to the context.
The value of the variable to add to the context.
member.remarks:
Value type conversion for XPath evaluation is as follows:
CLR Type XPath type
System.String XPathResultType.String
System.Double (or types that can be converted to) XPathResultType.Number
System.Boolean XPathResultType.Boolean
System.Xml.XPath.XPathNavigator XPathResultType.Navigator
System.Xml.XPath.XPathNodeIterator XPathResultType.NodeSet
Others XPathResultType.Any
See the topic "Compile, Select, Evaluate, and Matches with XPath and XPathExpressions" in MSDN documentation for additional information.
member.exception: The is null.
